Um, and then used the same grain of wood, you know, kind of like it was all like one piece, but maybe this was stained a little bit. And then I also made a a worn look or damaged. Oh, yeah. It just kind of made it look a little bit worn. Uh, just around the edges, some scratches, stuff like that. Okay, great. Good job. Good job. For sure. You got the you're controlling what direction the wood grain goes and uh yeah, you definitely did some experimenting here um with our different techniques. The thing that's more successful with the burning here is it looks like the burn was combined with some uh height and I think that makes it work look the burns look more convincing here than they did on the chair. I'm not it didn't even if you were doing the same thing there just didn't seem to Yeah, they really don't seem to pop in the same way that the the burn part do the burn part does over here. Um, yeah. So, I'm not gonna look up a bunch of like blood splatter reference right now for obvious reasons, but yeah, that's not what blood splatter looks. I mean, like, you know, I've been fortunate enough not to be around like a lot of blood splattering. Um, you know, not that kind of doctor. So, um, yeah. I mean, it's just usually a lot darker and, you know, like the tone of the red is usually a lot darker than you kind of like envision it being. a lot of instances and a multiply blend mode is usually something that's going to give you more of like a realistic blood um you know on top of something whereas this looks more like you know like paint or something. Um and then yeah you're just being pretty heavy with the height detail here. Um, so wherever the grain height is, either using the levels or just using the general height strength in the height stack to dial this off a little bit because, you know, it's like past the point where it looks like wood. Um, you that could also be adjusted in the final render environment as well, right? So this is exported back to Blender. Then you can um you know this is going to be height going into a bump map and the bump map have a has a strength slider which you could back it off there. So uh yeah you can we'll export uh these over but yeah you got the right uh the right idea there for that. That's looking that's looking good. Um the yeah I think you sort of take it to the next level. This crack is a really good idea but again I think I would try to either maybe put that um anchor point that into some height information so the crack starts to you know like either it's being either it's going in or it's like lifted out a little bit. Something like that would help take it to the next level. The just general uh scale of the wood grain on the table strikes me as a little small, right? Especially with wood grain looking at some reference and considering how big the table is because we're just even if we, you know, I'm not a carpenter, but like we have like a we're round this stuff all the time. you kind of have a feel for like how big the grain pattern is compared to the scale of the object. It does a lot to communicate the scale. So the table ends up looking kind of like small because of the way the wood grain is like the like I feel like the tiling on the wood grain pattern needs to go up in order to make that work 100%. But you're hitting all you're hitting all the major things there. Making some good progress for sure.

title: Quad Topology and Subdivision Surfaces
search_text: AVC185 November 03, 2025 Quad Topology and Subdivision Surfaces We know enough now to know quads good. Why are quads good? Uh because they fit really well into the subdivision surface workflow. And if we're able to use the subdivision surface modifier, that allows us to sort of arbitrarily and procedurally give our object more smoothness, which is very flexible, right? Because then when we're closer to an object, we're able to turn up the subdivision to give it more detail in its silhouette. And when we're further away, we could dial that down in order to give it less polygons. then um it would be faster to render and easier to use. But that works really well dialing up and down quads when they're part of a subd surface workflow. Um the subd becomes not so great when we have anything but quads, something like engon, right? How many sides in an engon. >> Uh well, more than four, right? Because three we're usually going to say try, right? And so um this when you subdivide this, you tend to get shading irregularities. Uh and when we subdivide quads, it's not, you know, impossible to get shading irregularities, but it just tends to be much much more solid. So that's just from a visual presentation standpoint. And this would just be for an object that is not deforming. If the object itself is deforming, like it's going to bend or anything like that, then the quads become really important and they, you know, animating an object that's not built out of quads is going to lead to a lot of problems with the surface distorting as the object moves. Whether it's with a modifier like a bend or twist modifier, or whether it's with bones moving some sort of mesh, there's It's both the same thing. There's some sort of animation happening to the vertices. And when the vertices are laid out and connected as quads, it's much much much better.

And when you have uh less detail, a smoother service, you don't need as much. You'd be wasting topology and data and possibly increasing render time by having denser topology on those areas. So you need some way to keep things quads, but then also be able to control where it's dense and where it's not. And so if you have some sort of straight uh UV island then it tries to put it diagonal like this. And it's doing that because it wants to magn max maximize texel density. However, this is the advantage that you're gaining. Some moderate increase in texal density on this piece I think is not worth the issues that this sort of unaligned island represents. Most of the time when we have long lengths of things like this, we kind of want the pattern to either go directly along the length or directly across the length. Most of the time that's the situation. Um, and so we don't have that here.

title: Student Feedback: Fast and Furious Analysis
search_text: AVC240 October 22, 2025 Student Feedback: Fast and Furious Analysis >> Hello. Hello. Here are my rendered shots for this week. Starting off with the realism scene. We have the full shot, the cowboy, medium close, and extreme close. And for my grease pencil scene, we have the medium full, medium, and closeup. I think my grease pencil shots work extra well at showing different narrative beats because of how the character progresses through actions as the shots change. The medium pull gives attention to the character and the environment that relates them to each other. The medium shot pulls into the character, and in this instance, the character picked up an object from the environment in the MFS, turning the prop into an extension of the character. And the close-up shot puts emphasis on the emotion the character is portraying and its relevance to the narrative. With the grease pencil scene, I drew the Pikachu parallel to the camera. It was a little awkward drawing with it for the first time, but I did appreciate how it essentially creates like a vector image that you can scale or change in the scene without like artifacting or similar issues. I'm pleased with how my renders turned out, but in the beginning, I was having a hard time coming up with inspiration for what kind of scenes I wanted to set up to demonstrate what shot size can do since I didn't want to just set up any scene and slap different zooms onto them. So, I did what anyone would do in these trying times and I watched three straight Fast and Furious movies. >> Approve. >> That's a straight up extra credit there. That's really great. >> We have someone watching free movies. And >> yeah, >> three straight Fast and Furious movies. And I ended up asking a lot of age-old questions like, "What is this franchise even about? What is going on?" And what did Vin Diesel mean by that? And I still have no idea, but it did help me understand how shots can be stylistic choices centered around the focus of the film, such as if lots of your shots are medium close-ups because you're always looking at your characters at the wheel of a car, or how the same shot type can have multiple uses depending on context and intention, and how a wide shot leading into a close shot can build tension and direct focus. And it was actually this exact scene that inspired my real [Laughter] [Music] Special thank you. >> Thanks. >> Mhm. >> These look great. They have like, you know, really like the color, the control of color here. This is a super, you know, strong vibe for the whole scene here. Um, great use of depth of field. Um the the the only thing here is that um I mean I'm I feel like for sure you did Well, I'm not sure if these are MixMo ladies or not. >> They are. >> They are. Yeah. like I I thought thought I recognized her. But um it's going to be a weird situation in real life when I see someone who I reminds me of a Miximo model and I'm like, "Wait, do I know you?" title: 180 Degree Rule Explanation
search_text: AVC240 October 20, 2025 180 Degree Rule Explanation 180 degree rule. >> Hold on. Is anyone hearing this? Angie, can you give me a thumbs up that you're receiving audio, please? Um, okay. So uh when we have two two characters talking to each other uh there's this uh line of action rule also called the 180 degree rule where uh everyone is sort of implicitly aware of this from watching you know a lifetime of television uh and movies that the camera placement needs to stay on one side of this line uh in order to do a couple things to keep the ey lines of the characters consistent on the screen. And so for instance, when this camera is filming, actor one is on the left side of the screen looking over to the right. And then when this camera is filing, actor two is on the right side of the screen looking over to the left. Um, and if you were to flip or if you were to cross the line at any point and place the camera over here, then the character's um position on the screen, meaning like where they are in the frame would change. it would flip to the other side and the direction that they're looking also would not be consistent. And this is just really disorienting for the most part. And um this is referred to as the 180 degree rule. And uh we'll try and set up a scene like this today. A lot of times, you know, what we'll do here is just sort of set up a typical um, you know, dialogue sort of scene. And so, we'll have a wide shot here where we establish the location and both characters in the space. And then as the characters go back and forth speaking, um, we can have, uh, we can set up multiple cameras. Uh, and usually what we want to have here, what we'll be learning about next week is we'll be framing each one uh, as an OTS shot, which means over the shoulder. And so we're kind of looking over the shoulder of actor two when actor one is uh, speaking. We're looking over the shoulder of actor one when actor two is speaking. We'll also combine uh some camera technique stuff here in that most often uh we're using some sort of shallow depth of field in that the back of the character that we're seeing here is not typically in focus. Obviously, the character that's speaking is in focus.

I think it's impressive how everything was created with CI yet looks completely realistic. Um, thanks for watching.

I feel that this element helps give a feeling of isolation. So, that's the vibe I was going for. For my depth render, I put the sword in the foreground and the character in the background with some depth of field. With this one, I think it works well to demonstrate that the objects in the fore and background have a direct relevance to each other. In my balance render, I really like the idea from my reference that the visual balance of a shot can allude to imbalance between the characters. So, I used the lighting and positioning of the characters to try and achieve that idea. And for my angle render, I tilted the camera to contrast with all the wouldbe horizontal lines in the shot. I think this is helpful in communicating that something is odd or offputting about the scene. From this video, I chose this frame. I think it's a good demonstration of balance with the symmetry of the room. And the asymmetry of the canvas is also an attention grabber. And I also liked this angled line from the door on the left into the canvas, then the couch, the cubes, and the identical door on the right. No questions, but a quick Blender tip I learned this week is about light linking. So, in this render, I wanted some extra shine on this sword, but I didn't want to make lights that would affect the rest of the scene. So, to do that, you just make whatever light you want. Come into the object properties, shading, and light linking. Select the collection that your objects are in, and then you can either select the objects you want to be affected or unselect the objects you don't want to be affected.
